title: Module 3 - sections
instruction: Click on each section to find out more.

_items.title: Qualitative sampling and recruitment
_items.body:
In this section we will cover:

  • recruitment matrixes - what they are and why they're useful 
  • recruitment agencies - the advantages and disadvantages
  • the use of incentives in research

_items.title: Qualitative research methods
_items.body:
This section will introduce you to:

  • some universal considerations for conducting qualitative research
  • qualitative research methods - including when they may or may not be appropriate
  • online vs offline considerations in research

_items.title: Qualitative reporting and analysis
_items.body:
This section will:

  • give an overview of the considerations you need to make when analysing, and reporting on, your qualitative data. ​
  • it won't be a step-by-step guide on how to conduct qualitative analysis, but will cover everything you need to be aware of in order to start thinking about your analysis and report writing.

title: Introduction to Module 3: Qualitative research methods and analysis
body:
Welcome to Module 3 of Data Collection Fundamentals. 

 

This Module will begin to introduce different qualitative research methods, and will cover:​

  • qualitative sampling and recruitment​

  • qualitative research methods​

  • qualitative reporting and analysis

title: New Component Title
body:
In this module, we covered:

  • qualitative Sampling and recruitment – consider whether in-house recruitment is feasible, or if you will need a recruitment agency. A recruitment matrix can help with defining your recruitment process.​

  • qualitative research methods – understand the contexts in which methods are and aren't appropriate and decide whether your research should be online or offline​

  • qualitative reporting and Analysis – consider how to prepare, analyse and report on the qualitative data collected

title: Recruitment matrixes
body:
A recruitment matrix is a grid which helps you to specify and manage your recruitment. We recommend developing a recruitment matrix for your research. A recruitment matrix will:​

  • allow you to ensure that you capture diversity within your sample. Within a recruitment matrix you specify which criteria are important to your research. This will depend on what your research aims are and who your intended respondent is. You might consider different characteristics such as demographics (age or sex for example), experiences, attitudes or beliefs for example. When you have decided your criteria, you should think about what the target number of participants within those criteria might be.  ​

  • assist you to decide how you will recruit. Different types of respondents may need to be recruited in different ways. You should always consider the bias in your recruitment method. For example, recruiting solely via an online advert may exclude anyone who is less digitally confident, or who doesn’t have access to the internet. This will mean that those types of respondent might not be captured in your research findings. It might therefore be appropriate to recruit in numerous different ways. ​

  • allow you to keep track of the respondent characteristics which you have tested with. After each testing effort you can note your “achieved” numbers against each characteristic. This will allow you to identify any “gaps” in your recruitment; i.e. under sampling of particular characteristics.

title: Recruitment agencies
body:
Recruitment can be a resource and time intensive part of the testing process. You will need to undertake several steps, including multiple contacts with potential participants. This includes initial contact, booking of the interview, reminders and follow up after the research session. Because of this you may decide to employ a recruitment agency to recruit participants on your behalf.

There are both advantages and disadvantages of using a recruitment agency. Expand the sections below for more information.

_items.title: Advantages of recruitment agencies
_items.body:
The benefits of using an agency include: 

  • reputation and awareness: The agency might already have a good reputation and be trusted by the public ​

  • access: The agency might have a diverse pool of potential participants at their disposal ​

  • recruitment opportunities: The agency might recruit via different methods and already have different organisations and gatekeepers to source participants from ​

  • frees up resource: Employing an agency means that the work doesn’t have to be done in house. This frees up resource to direct towards other activities ​

  • access to venues: The agency may have testing suites which you can hire or use ​

  • consent: The agency may ensure consent is provided whilst recruiting, meaning this does not need to be done in-team. However, you should always check that the participant has been safeguarded appropriately ​

  • safety: The agency may screen its potential participants, meaning the risk to researchers is reduced compared to if you're recruiting yourself. Internal screening will still take place to ensure eligibility. Agencies may also handle incentive payments, meaning researchers do not have to handle cash. Confirm consent before proceeding with your research.  ​

  • rescheduling: The agency will usually handle cancellation and rescheduling, which can be very time consuming for the in house team otherwise

_items.title: Disadvantages of recruitment agencies
_items.body:
However, it must also be noted that there are some disadvantages to using an agency, such as:

  • participants may have taken part in similar research before. This can influence their behaviour and damage the quality of the research. You can mitigate this at least partially by asking the agency to screen out participants who have undertaken similar research previously. ​

  • agencies may recruit via an online application form. This might mean that you are more likely to gain access to digital confident, internet enable participants. You can request alternative avenues of recruitment if this is important to your research ​

  • you can lose control over the sample as you as the researcher are not actively recruiting your own sample, i.e. you may not make the same decisions as an agency researcher (this could also, however, sometimes be an advantage)​

  • there might be additional considerations or concerns about confidentiality and GDPR. Must obtain additional consent from participants to share info between agency and your organisation, and implement protocols to ensure data is stored securely. For this reason, using an agency might not be appropriate for very sensitive topics.​

  • there is a cost associated with outsourcing recruitment

title: Independent recruitment
body:
If you cannot employ an agency to recruit on your behalf, you will need to carry out this activity yourself. You will need to decide what type of sampling strategy to use. In qualitative research you will use non-probability sampling methods. This means using purposive sampling, where you 'purposively' select each participant because they have certain characteristics or features which relate to the research topic which is being explored. This will be reflected in your research grid and recruitment matrix. ​

There are different ways of recruiting participants. For example:​

  • placing an advert in a newspaper or on social media.​

  • asking friends, family or colleagues to pass details of the research onto people they know​

  • recontacting people who have used the service or taken part in a Live survey, for example. However, you will need to ensure that you have gained adequate permission to recontact during their first interaction. ​

  • using a gatekeeper. This might mean approaching a charity or businesses of interest for example. These can act as gatekeepers to pass information about your research to other interested parties. ​

It is important to be organised in your approach. Do not underestimate the amount of time the recruitment phase might take.  Be prepared to undertake additional recruitment to sample subsets of your sample design that may be more difficult to access. You will also need to consider any ethical implications.

title: The use of incentives
body:
You may need to provide an incentive to participants of your research.​

If you are using a recruitment agency, this may be done on your behalf.​

Otherwise, you will need to think about the type and size of incentive which is appropriate, for example, cash or a voucher. You will also need to consider how you will administer the incentive (e.g., will this be in person? Emailed to the participant? Bank transfer?)​

The incentive should be given as an unconditional “thank you for your time”, not as a payment for services (as this is coercion). It should be provided to any participants that attend an interview, regardless of whether they drop out of the interview or not.

title: Summary of qualitative sampling and recruitment
displayTitle: Summary of qualitative sampling and recruitment
body:
This section should have introduced you to some of the considerations you need to make when recruiting participants.​

Remember that the way in which you do your recruitment can affect the quality of your research-​

  • developing a recruitment matrix can help to define your recruitment process​

  • consider whether you would benefit from using a recruitment agency. Familiarise yourself with the strengths and limitations so that you can decide whether this would be suitable in your research.​

  • think about whether incentives would be appropriate in your research, and if so, what incentives would be appropriate.

title: Preparing for qualitative research
body:
Here are some of the things you need to prepare before beginning your research:​

  • you will need to formulate the purpose of the investigation i.e. your research aims. These aims will inform your research materials e.g. a topic guide, visual aids etc. ​

  • consider how much time and resource you have for this research. At project initiation, produce realistic timescales for the following components of qualitative research: Establishing requirements, developing research materials, sampling and recruitment, conducting your qualitative research, charting, analysis and reporting. Note that these are not exhaustive – you may have more components, for example, quantitative testing, that you also need to consider.​

  • it's a good idea to have another researcher help you. You will need to clearly define roles before you being your research, for example: define who will ask questions and who will note-take (make sure the note-taker understands how you need the notes to be taken), who will screenshare or share any materials with the respondent and who will start the recording/ transcript.  ​

  • consider the location of your research setting. Is this accessible for all participants? Is it a suitable location? Consider when online research might work better than offline (in-person) research.​

  • think about recording and/ or transcribing before you begin your research – do you require software to do this for you?​

  • the way the research is conducted will affect the quality of the data that you get out of it. This means it’s important that the researcher is fully trained in the method chosen. 

Below are some key things to remember when preparing for your qualitative research.

_items.title: Reflexivity
_items.body:
What’s really important (and is something we have already mentioned), is the relationship between the participant/s and the researcher. The relationship should be developed in a way that that goals of both the researcher and the participant are met, whilst feeling valued and respected throughout. ​

The concept of “reciprocity” is also important here – this is where the researcher and participant should both benefit from the research, with an equal amount of giving and taking. The closer the researcher can get to the participant, the more authentic the insights become. ​

To build a good relationship with the participant/s, it’s important for the researcher to be reflexive. This means, examining your own judgements, beliefs and practices to identify anything that may have affected the research. To be truly reflexive, you must also be prepared to question your own assumptions. For instance, what type of assumptions might this be referring to? How might the researcher actively impact research? How can this be combatted? You must also be accepting of the fact that the researcher can actively influence the outcome of the research. 

Imagine you're conducting research about a topic you have innate assumptions about. These could be deep-rooted assumptions you have, or new assumptions that you've picked up whilst interviewing previous respondents for the same piece of research. ​

If you're not aware of these personal biases, you might end up asking a leading question, 'Why don't you like XYZ?', or fail to properly ask follow-up probes if a respondent expresses a view that is different to your own.​

By being aware of your own potential biases, and the impact this can have on research, it's easier to recognise how to act and respond in an impartial manner, and ensure the data you gather is a reflection of the participant, and not yourself​

Reflexivity aims to take some of the focus off of the participant and onto the researcher, with an overall aim of recognising and identifying how the study could be impacted by the researcher.

_items.title: Topic guides
_items.body:
A topic guide is a document that structures the course of the research session. They are most commonly used in interview and focus group settings. Your topic guide can include a sequence of carefully thought out questions, or can just list some topics that you want to cover during your interview. You will need to use probing techniques to yield further information from your participants. ​

Probing is where the researcher asks follow-up questions when; they do not fully understand a response; when answers are vague or ambiguous; or when they want to yield more in-depth information. ​

Questions you prepare in your topic guide should be brief, simple, and use language that the interviewee/s will be familiar with. The data you collect won't be of good quality if participants are misunderstanding the question, and are providing an answer to a different question than the one you've intended. The principles of question design we covered in Module 2 should be applied here.​

Your topic guide should be designed to answer your research aims. When thinking about questions to include in your topic guide, it might help if you write down what you aim to get out of that question, or how the response could help you to answer your research question.

title: Qualitative research methods
body:
We will now look and some of the most commonly used qualitative research methods, giving an overview of what the method is, and some examples of when they may or may not be appropriate to use. 

Note that the list of methods covered in this course is not exhaustive.

_items.title: In-depth interviews
_items.body:
Overview of method

Interviews are an unstructured or semi-structured conversation, where the purpose has been pre-determined by the interviewer. ​Interviews allow the researcher to better explore, understand and explain the participant’s opinions, behaviours, experiences etc. They are one-on-one sessions with an interviewer (I.e., the researcher) and a participant and tend to last around an hour. ​

They require a careful questioning and listening approach to obtain the necessary information. It's important to build a rapport and trust with the participant.  If the interviewee feels as though they’re being listened to and valued, they are more likely to share information with you. ​

The researcher will use the pre-designed topic guide to ask the participant questions related to the research objectives. The researcher should create a safe space for the participant to share information. ​

The participant may talk about something that you hadn’t prepared for in your topic guide, so it’s important to be flexible and adapt your questioning to yield the insights you need. This will allow you to follow up on new or emerging topics of interest. 

 

When would an interview be an appropriate method?

  • when researching people’s understanding, meanings and/or experiences​

  • when clarifying and elaborating on participants' perceptions​

  • when researching sensitive topics (participants may feel more comfortable sharing information in the one-to-one setting, rather than in a group)​

  • when you may need to adapt your questioning to yield the relevant insights​

  • when research topics are complex and need explaining​

  • if the research is open to unexpected or emerging topics

 

When would an interview not be the most appropriate method?

  • when you need to make statistical inferences from your data​

  • when you have little time to conduct your research (qualitative is often (but not always) more time consuming than quantitative research – but this will depend on the context of the research)​

  • when the research would benefit from group conversations – in this situation, it would be best to use a different qualitative method, such as a focus group.

_items.title: Focus groups
_items.body:
Overview of method

Focus groups are a form of group interview led by a moderator. There are usually between 3-12 participants in one focus group. The number of participants will likely depend on the mode used, for example it is common to have more participants in face-to-face focus groups than in online focus groups. The participants will be put into groups of similar characteristics that are of interest to the topic being researched. This doesn't however mean that they should have similar attitudes, demographics, experiences etc in general – only the characteristics of interest to the research should be similar. Focus groups are typically longer in length than in-depth interviews as you need to consider the group interactions and discussions. They tend to last around 90 minutes, but this will depend on the nature of your research. Consider how many questions or topics you need to get through in the time allocated. ​

The moderator is there to: ​

  • encourage interaction among group members​

  • ensure everyone has the chance to participate​

  • regulate dominant group members​

  • keep the conversation on track​

  • summarise any points made by participants. ​

The moderator needs to be impartial and non-judgemental. ​

This is a less directive style of interviewing from the moderator than with in-depth interviews. This is because the moderator will encourage a variety of views on the topic in question and will let participants discuss them as a group.​

The aim of a focus group is to bring forward different viewpoints on an issue or particular topic. 

There may be personal and conflicting viewpoints, so the moderator will need to encourage a safe space. ​

Where necessary, the moderator will need to be skilful in closing any dominant participants down, whilst still making them feel valued. They will also try to encourage any quieter participants to get more involved and share their thoughts/ opinions. ​

The moderator will need to ensure that everyone’s opinions are respected and that everyone is aware of the confidentiality of the session.

 

When would a focus group be an appropriate method?

  • when the research would benefit from group depth (group discussions, challenging opinions, idea sharing etc)​

  • when you want to get a breadth of thoughts/ experiences from people with similar characteristics e.g. individuals with a similar health condition or similar job role​

  • to collect a range of diverse opinions quickly​

  • when you know little about the research topic 

 

When would a focus group not be the most appropriate method?

  • if the research topic is sensitive or of a personal nature​

  • if there are any concerns over anonymity ​

  • when you have structured your questions or have a fixed order of questioning​

​Note: There can be more practical implications to consider when organising focus groups. It can sometimes be difficult to find a suitable time and/or location when multiple participants are involved. You’ll have to consider the feasibility when planning your research and recruiting participants. 

 

When to use a focus group rather than an interview

The decision on whether to use a focus group or one-to-one interview will largely depend on the context of the study. ​

It will depend on factors such as the research purpose, or whether the advantages and disadvantages of group discussion will positively or negatively affect your findings.​

Timings will also play a role - focus group enables quicker fieldwork periods as you can do four groups instead of thirty depth interviews, for example. ​

The researcher should make an informed decision based on what is most suitable for the research in question.

_items.title: Pop-up research
_items.body:
Overview of method

Pop-up research consists of short, informal interviews or usability testing, in the places used by the people you are interested in speaking to. Usability testing would involve taking the product or service with you and observing participant’s using it. Short interviews would involve asking participant’s a set of questions whilst being in their own environment. ​

Pop-up research could talk place in a café, university campus, shops etc – anywhere that is used by those you're aiming to speak to. Unlike other methods, this means you won't recruit participants prior to the event, and will instead, recruit them there and then. The implication of this is that you then have a biased sample as a result of the recruitment method.​

It is a quick and low-cost method of conducting research and works best when you have clear and simple objectives. Pop-up research should always be done in pairs – this is both safer and easier. ​

It’s important to prioritise the questions you need answering for your research, as you don’t know how much time people will be willing to spend with you. Focus on the prioritised questions first to be sure you’ve got the most important information. 

When would pop-up research be an appropriate method?

  • pop-up research can give just about enough insight in the early stages when you’re exploring different problems and opportunities. It can also increase your understanding for when you design more in-depth research. ​

  • if you're researching ‘hard to reach’ populations, for example those in care homes ​

  • if you want to research regional variations (you would need to repeat the research in multiple locations)

 

When would pop-up research not be the most appropriate method?

  • pop-up research shouldn’t ever be used as a standalone method – there are many limitations (e.g. short sessions, biased sample, unexpected challenges) which mean it should always be used in combination with an alternative research method.

_items.title: Usability testing
_items.body:
Usability testing is seeing how easy or difficult something is to use by testing it with real users. ​

They are one-to-one sessions where users are asked to complete tasks whilst being observed by a researcher. The researcher will ask the user to 'think aloud' whilst interacting with the product or service. After the ‘think aloud’ session, the researcher will then probe about any issues that arose.​

In research, usability testing could be used to discover how easy a questionnaire is to respond to, for example. By testing the questionnaire, the researcher can see first-hand how the users, navigate through the survey, fix any error messages, identify and understand icons, know how to save and exit, and so on. This allows the researcher to then develop the questionnaire further (i.e. making it easier to respond to) based on the insights gathered from the usability testing.

_items.title: Cognitive interviewing
_items.body:
Cognitive Interviewing was covered in Module 2, but just as a reminder:​

  • cognitive interviews are one-to-one sessions with a participant and a researcher. The purpose of the interview is to evaluate the quality and comprehension of survey questions.​

  • they aim to study the ways in which individuals mentally process and respond to survey questions.​

  • cognitive interviewing can increase the understanding of question validity (the extent to which your questionnaire measures what it purports to measure) and response error (the return of false or subjectively modified information from survey respondents). It does this by tapping into participants’ mental models, learning about their thought process, how they arrive at their answer, and so on.​

  • a common technique used in cognitive interviewing is encouraging the participant to ‘think aloud’. This means, verbalising their thoughts and processes as they answer questions or interact with a service.​

  • you will use probing techniques to ensure you get the information you need from the participant

_items.title: 'Cogability' testing
_items.body:
Although usability testing uses similar approaches to that of cognitive interviewing, it's important to know that they are different methods, which aim to gather different insights. Whilst some issues with questions may come to light in usability testing for example, it requires full cognitive probing to understand how users have understood questions and arrived at their answers. This means that one method cannot be used as a substitute for another. ​

It can, therefore, be beneficial to conduct usability and cognitive interviewing simultaneously, given the interactions between question wording, instrument design and the response process. This is known as 'cogability testing'.​

Cogability testing, user testing, and cognitive interviewing are generally used for self-completion surveys, where there is no interviewer present.

title: Qualitative research methods, continued...
body: Whilst we have covered the most commonly used qualitative methods, there are other methods which are important to be aware of. These include:

_items.title: Observations
_items.body:
This method involves collecting data through observing. It may involve watching, listening, reading etc. to record behaviour. The aim of an observation is to attempt to understand behaviours by getting to know the person in their natural environment.​

Observations can be structured (where there are defined variables and objectives) or unstructured (where there are no pre-determined variables or objectives). ​

They can also be overt (where research subjects are aware they are being observed) or covert (where research subjects are not aware they are being observed). Covert observations tend to capture more natural behaviours, but be sure to be aware of ethical issues that are associated with this method.​

Whilst observations are considered to have greater accuracy (as the researcher can directly check data from what they observe), not all behaviours are open to observation which means they’re not always suitable. ​

People are also known to change their behaviour when they know they are being observed, which can affect the validity of the research – this is called the Hawthorne Effect.

_items.title: Participatory methods
_items.body:
Participatory methods have the objective of handing the power over from the researcher to the participant. ​

The researcher will explain the exercise, and then the participant will generate their own data through the use of the tool or exercise. The data is often visual, so works well with children and those who are less literate. ​

When conducting participatory research in a group setting, the session is interactive, involving working together and having discussions. The researcher will encourage participants to reflect on the information generated throughout the exercise, to obtain findings and gain insights. ​

Ranking and scoring exercises would be an example of participatory research.​

Participatory research can be used alone, or they can be used alongside other qualitative methods, such as in-depth interviews or a focus group.​

This method would be helpful in the discovery phase of your research.

_items.title: Deliberative research
_items.body:
Deliberative research focuses on uncovering participant’s attitudes and viewpoints, after they have been given an opportunity to ‘deliberate’ the issue. The general structure is as follows: ​

Phase 1 – Learning. This is where participants are given impartial evidence on the issue/s in question.​

Phase 2 – Deliberating. Participants will then discuss the issue within the group.​

Phase 3 – Decision making. Finally, participants will be asked to make a decision, based on the evidence and their discussions. ​

This method seeks to understand differing viewpoints and perspectives, and aims to provide a range of information on the topic in hand. ​

Deliberation can build support for policy decisions, making it a useful method when researching public attitudes to policy problems, for example.

_items.title: Ethnography
_items.body:
Ethnography involves observing people in their own environment to understand their experiences, perspectives and everyday practices. This makes ethnography a good method for getting a deeper understanding of design problems. It is also commonly used to explore different cultures or behaviours, or to inform policy development. ​

This method is mostly used in the early stages of a user-centred design project, as it focuses on understanding any design problems. ​

Ethnographic research can help to identify unexpected issues and will give detailed understanding of the user’s behaviour and attitudes. ​

This type of research, however, does tend to take longer than other methods due to the nature of the research.

_items.title: Offline considerations
_items.body:
Sometimes, it is necessary for you to conduct research in person. When conducting face-to-face research there are useful things to consider:​

If you have the time to physically attend the required research sessions. For example, when conducting research offline, this can take more time (than online research) due to any associated travelling.​

Make sure the location is suitable for you to conduct the research but also for your participants. You may wish to consider a neutral location or somewhere the participant feels more comfortable and has suitable access needs. Consider if you will reimburse your participants if they need to travel to a location to participate.​

In a focus group setting, it may be beneficial to have two facilitators. Often, one is dedicated to note-taking whilst the other hold the conversation or discussion. ​

Assess risk and researcher safety, for example, if the research offers a cash incentive and the researcher is carrying this with them.

_items.title: Online considerations
_items.body:
Sometimes, it might be better for you to conduct your research online, rather than face-to-face or over the telephone. If you decide that online works best for your research, there are further things that you will need to consider: ​

​
Ensuring appropriate environments

Participants sometimes find online research less formal, and whilst this does have its benefits, they should ensure that they’re in an appropriate environment to take part. For example, you want participants to be engaged, and not laying down in bed or watching TV. You’ll also need to consider whether the conversation could be overheard, especially in the context of the sensitive topics. For example, if the participant is in a café taking part in the research over Skype, Teams or Zoom, it’s likely that passersby will be able to listen in. When arranging interviews, provide guidance to participants regarding the environment they should undertake the study in.​

You should also ask participants to minimise any distractions. For example turning their phone on silent, or asking them not to check their emails for the duration of the session. ​

Give participants the option to put their cameras on. Having cameras turned on can make it easier for the interviewer to see if someone is trying to speak. This can also help to build rapport. 

 

Accessibility and technology

You’ll need to consider accessibility needs for everyone to be able to participate online. Does everyone in your sample have access to the internet? Can they all use a technological device needed for the research?​

Provide instructions on how to access or download the platform you intend to use e.g. Zoom, Microsoft Teams, Google Meet etc. Ensure that everyone can access the platform before the research starts.​

If conducting research in a large group, consider using breakout rooms. It may be beneficial to have a facilitator in each group to capture conversation and keep the conversation on track where necessary. ​

Be aware of technical limitations, for example when conducting an interview, consider having a telephone number you can call as a back up option if technology fails you.​

Consider using the chat function or other online tools during the research, for example a Miro Board. This may help to keep participants engaged. You would need to check everyone has access beforehand. Also think about the sensitivity of the topic before introducing other online tools. ​

Consider GDPR – for example, how does the platform you’re using store information? Do you need secure connections? Ensure you adhere to company guidelines. ​

Think about how you’re going to record and transcribe your interview or focus group. Does the platform you’re using have the functionality to do this for you, or will you have to prepare to do this yourself? 

 

Communications

Schedule a calendar invite with appropriate reminders. People will be busy with their day-to-day lives, so give them gentle reminders so that they don’t forget the time and/or date of the research.​

Let participants know how you want them to communicate during the research. For example, if in a focus group, do you want participants to use the ‘hands up’ function, or can they just jump in and start talking? If being conducted online and the platform has a chat function, let participants know that they can use that function if they don’t feel comfortable speaking aloud. If conducting a focus group and encouraging use of the chat function, it might be beneficial to have someone with you to monitor the chat. Set these expectations of how you want participants to contribute, before discussing your topics of interest.

title: Summary of qualitative research methods
body:
• this section should have introduced you to some of the most common methods used in qualitative research, as well as any biases to be aware of.​

  • this should help to inform your decisions when designing and planning qualitative research. Think about when methods are and are not appropriate and consider the context of your study when designing your research. Think about the extra considerations you need to make if you’re wanting to conduct your research online – is the method still appropriate? ​

  • remember that all methods have their strengths and limitations and knowing these will help you to make an informed decision and yield the best data from your research. ​

  • use any insights you've gathered from your research to iterate your design. This will ensure that your products or services are designed based on user needs. ​

  • it’s important for anyone conducting qualitative research to be properly trained – these methods require certain skills, which aren’t always obvious. An interviewer who is trained for example, will not only improve the interview experience for the interviewee, but will also provide more detailed and accurate data for your analysis. This is vital to ensure you come to the right conclusions and develop the most effective recommendations.

title: Summarising your data
body:
Read through your transcriptions before starting your analysis.  The more familiar you are with the data, the easier it will be for you to draw out themes in the analysis.  ​

You and your team should summarise and analyse your data for recurring themes. A number of methods are used to achieve this, including:​

  • use of analysis software such as Nvivo, RDQA​

  • constructing an Excel spreadsheet (a charting document) with the data organised into topic guide probes or themes. ​

Throughout this process, researchers should check each other’s work to ensure they are finding similar themes, this increases the validity of the research by avoiding researcher bias.

title: Charting
body:
Charting involves summarising the data by topic or theme. Your charting framework should be based on:​

  • your topic guide, user requirements and emerging themes​

  • any interviewer observations​

  • overarching comments​

You should include the context and any relevant quotations in your charting document. ​

Good charting has a balance between reducing the amount of data whilst retaining the original meaning and ‘feel’ of the interviewee's words.

title: Data analysis
body:
Qualitative analysis can be conducted on the summaries you have written. ​

The process of qualitative analysis involves looking for emerging themes, as well as the similarities and differences in the data. Look for any repeated themes within the data as well as any issues which are contested. Remember this is a bottom-up, descriptive and interpretive approach - let the data guide you when establishing your themes. ​

You want to look for the range and nature of findings, rather than the extent. This means you shouldn’t quantify any of your findings or use quantifying language such as; ‘some’, ‘many’, ‘the majority’ etc. ​

Remember to draw out the solutions and/or recommendations in your findings as this will be important for the report.

title: Reporting
body: There are a few considerations you need to make when reporting your findings:

_items.title: Consider your audience
_items.body:
It is critical to establish with the data user what sort of report they expect from you and its format - if they want a word document, presentation, spreadsheet or Miro board.​

Examples of different audiences:​

  • reports for academics or other methodologists will be formal and detailed and will contain sections about the methodology used and ethics.​

  • reports for ministers and policy makers will be brief, have little to say about the methodology and ethics, but will focus on the take home messages from the findings.

_items.title: The type of qualitative project
_items.body:
Qualitative projects differ, but below are examples of two ways of reporting based on type of qualitative project:

  • reporting cognitive interviewing will focus on the questions tested.  You may want to use Red/Amber/Green status to indicate how well a question worked or did not work and use evidence from analysis and participant quotations to demonstrate this.​

  • reporting focus groups or in-depth interviews will have richer detail about how participants from different groups or circumstances approached the topic.  They may also explore things like acceptability and ethics as well as understanding/recall.

_items.title: Recommendations
_items.body:
• recommendations may be in the form of actions for the stakeholder to implement following the research, or may be suggestions for further investigation. ​

  • recommendations should aim to solve any problems discovered in the study. They should only be based within the context of the study, and not go beyond it. Ensure that your recommendations are actionable and rationalised.

_items.title: Key things to remember
_items.body:
1. Do not use numbers or quantifying language, instead use phrases like:-​

  • ‘Among the participants the view was expressed that …’​

  • ‘One of the themes that emerged was …’​

2. Identify types of participant in your report:

  • ‘Among participants who identified as trans, the opinion was that …’​

  •  That way you can demonstrate to your reader the difference in ​opinion between groups.​

3. Maintain anonymity and confidentiality of respondents in your analysis and reporting. Remove any identifiable characteristics, such as names, job titles etc. Respondents have spoken to you in confidence, so it’s important to use your judgement and remove any words or sentences which may make them identifiable.

title: Summary of qualitative reporting and analysis
displayTitle: Summary of qualitative reporting and analysis
body:
• transcriptions should accurately reflect the raw data – remember to familiarise yourself with the transcriptions before starting your analysis.​

  • don't try to quantify your findings​

  • use a charting framework to effectively summarise your data by topic or theme.​

  • it's important to quality assure your charting and analysis as this will help to avoid researcher bias.​

  • remember your audience when reporting your findings and recommendations – this will determine the type of report you produce.​

  • remember that recommendations should be actionable and justified.​

  • keep confidentiality and anonymity of participants at the forefront of your mind throughout any analysis and reporting activities.

title: Course checklist
body:
The checklist below will highlight what has been covered throughout the 3 modules in this course. Remember, you can go back to any module at any point. 

  • An introduction to data collection – what is it and how can it be used? ​

  • Planning data collection – using research grids to help establish your research aims​

  • Agile Delivery – remember the importance of reiteration and flexible design​

  • User centred design – understanding customer and user needs, and developing with the user at the centre of the design ​

  • Accessibility and Inclusivity – your service must be inclusive and accessible to all – ensure you're adhering to the relevant guidelines​

  • Ethics in data collection – be aware of different ethical issues that may arise, and use this to aid your decision making​

  • Research planning – using research grids to help plain your research, and developing your communication strategy​

  • Survey design​ (an introduction) - User requirements and conceptualisation: investigate and scope out what is required from the research ​

  • Questionnaire design – adhere to best practice to ensure you are getting the most out of the responses, with little burden on the respondent​

  • Methods and Modes – adopt the most appropriate mode for your research- sometimes, mixed-methods may be the most appropriate​

  • Quantitative testing approaches - evaluation and testing your survey or service development​

  • Qualitative sampling and recruitment – use a recruitment matrix to help plan your recruitment processes​

  • Qualitative research methods – understanding the contexts in which methods are and aren't appropriate​

  • Qualitative reporting and analysis – consider how to prepare, analyse and report on the data collected

title: Test your knowledge
instruction: Would it be appropriate to use an interview to research COVID-19 infection rates?

_feedback.correct: Correct! Interviews would not be an appropriate method to gather quantitative data.

_incorrect.final: Incorrect. Interviews should be used to gather Qualitative data. Data such as infection rates should be gathered via Quantitative means.

title: New Component Title
instruction: Should pop-up research be used as a robust, standalone research method?

_feedback.correct: Correct! Pop-up research should always be used in combination with an alternative research method.

_incorrect.final: Incorrect. Pop-up research should always be used in combination with an alternative research method.

title: New Component Title
instruction: Is the following statement True or False? 'Cognitive interviewing can be used as a substitute for Usability testing?'

_feedback.correct: Correct! Whilst the methods use similar approaches, one should never be used as a substitute for the other.

_incorrect.final: Incorrect. Both methods aim to gather different insights, meaning that whilst the methods could be used together (i.e.,'Cogability testing'), they should never be used as a substitute for one another.
